title: American_Top_40_1980_June_28th
description:
"Every week on American Top 40 we count down the most popular songs from Sydney, North Dakota, to Melbourne, Kentucky; from Perth, Kansas, to Brisbane, California. And from Australia, here is the group Air Supply at number 28 with, 'Lost In Love'."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is one I found on the internet.

In this countdown:

There is a song in the countdown that was written only an hour before it was first performed live at an audition for record company executives.

There is a single by a 64-year-old singer who first hit the charts forty years prior.

Casey gives a special report on "movie music" in the 80s so far, and says this countdown sets a record for most movie songs in the top 40 (eight of them).

The Pretenders are at number 22. Casey explains what the title, "Brass In Pocket" means.

"Tired Of Toein' The Line" (at number 18) is by Rocky Burnette, whom Casey says contributed his name to the word "Rockabiliy,"

Casey remembers the childhood of Jerry Leiber which provided the background for him (and his partner Mike Stoller) to write shuch hits as "Hound Dog", "Jailhouse Rock", "Don't", "Kansas City", and "Stand By Me."

LW#3; Biggest Part Of Me - Ambrosia
